Award.AwardTitle: Energy Harvesting in Flows Using Parasitic Aeroelastic Structures and Nonlinear Switching Electronics

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Research Objectives and Approach: The research objective is to develop a novel energy harvesting method for self-powered devices. If one could develop sensing circuits that required no power, then the amount of wiring which leads directly to maintenance and production costs could be greatly reduced. It is proposed to develop energy harvesters to create sensor networks that could constantly report on the health of a variety of critical structures. The proposed approach will develop methods of power harvesting from fluid flow using aeroelastic systems and smart power electronic circuits. Using piezoelectric structures, these devices will be capable of converting flow-induced vibrations into storable electrical energy. Nonlinear switching circuits will be developed to enhance the efficiency of transducer electromechanical power extraction.

Intellectual Merit: This work also represents fundamental research into a heretofore untapped source of energy for self-powered systems, i.e., the movement of fluid air and water. The results of this work will give engineers the analytical tools to determine how to harvest power from fluid flows. This could aid in the development of condition-based systems of maintenance for future and existing infrastructures.

Broader impact: This project will disseminate information for K-12 students by creating teaching modules in cooperation with local middle and high school teachers. These modules will be made available to schools on the web to demonstrate the idea of energy harvesting from the environment. Local teachers will be invited to a workshop at Cornell with their students to help create lessons and experiments for use in K-12 classrooms.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project, broadly about harnessing electric energy more efficiently from wind and water flows, ultimately had three objectives with the majority of work being carried out on objectives (2) and (3).

Objectives:

(1) To increase the potential energy yield in airflow with the use of deformable (aeroelastic) structures and nonlinear switching devices that allow energy extraction to be optimized from piezoelectric devices (transducers that convert stress to energy).

(2) To increase the potential for wind energy at an urban building's rooftop by modifying the building's facade to accelerate the wind at the roof while minimizing turbulence. 

(3) To increase the vertical entrainment of horizontal momentum (harvestable energy) within an array of turbines (i.e., a wind farm), motivated by allowing wind farms to extract more energy per unit area of land and thus reducing the cost of wind or water flow generated electricity.

Under the first objective an existing piezoelectric device (the Cornell Flapper) was placed in our wind tunnel to validate theoretical data in the literature.

Under the second objective, a series of experiments were performed at 1:300 scale in a wind tunnel where care was taken to replicate the near-ground (boundary layer) flow in a physically realistically way such as is encountered in urban environments. This was achieved by using a combination of cubes and cylinders (roughness elements) mounted to the floor of the wind tunnel upstream of the building being tested. Measurements of the mean wind speed enhancement and turbulence characteristics were made at three locations along the roof top of the building being tested: at the leading edge, a middle location, and trailing end of the roof top. Comparisons were made to a base case, a rectangular building model. All facade modifications (sloped, elliptical and rose shaped configurations) caused an increase in the mean wind speed directly above the roof in addition to a decrease in the turbulence intensities at the middle location and trailing end, demonstrating building facade modifications can be used to increase the availability of wind energy at building roof tops. The ability to increase mean wind speed with reduced turbulence intensities is important as higher turbulence levels are known to lead to more rapid wind turbine failures. Results were genialized using computational fluid dynamics simulations.

Under the third objective, the plan included developing an 18-turbine array of tightly calibrated electrical energy generating turbines which allow accurate understanding of how varying the operation of individual turbines within the array, such that an individual turbine might not be running at its maximally efficient setting, allows the overall array to operate more efficiently, i.e., produce more power than if each turbine was simply set to run at its maximum efficient energy generation setting. A novel torque transducer calibration was developed that increased the accuracy of our model turbine power generation measurements by a factor of five or more driving the uncertainty in our measurements down to about 2%. A single turbine experiment that compared a turbine in steady optimal operation compared to unsteady suboptimal operation demonstrated accelerated turbine wake decay, a sign of enhanced vertical mixing of wind energy from above down into the wake, an indicator of potential improved turbine array performance. We are just completing the assembly of the 18-turbine array and plan to test control algorithms across the turbines to demonstrate improved energy generation from the 18-turbine array relative to the base case of each turbine running at its optimal setting. This work is being carried out under other funding and will be completed in 2019.

Under funding for this project two PhDs were supported, one of which has already been awarded to a URM, the other should be completed in 2019. Further, five undergraduates have worked on this project over its course, one of whom has gone on to a PhD program at Stanford University and two others are now interested in a research-based graduate degree. The new 18-turbine array is a unique piece of laboratory infrastructure that will provide researchers a new tool to test and optimize wind farms.
